commit_message:
Developing Murano Packages 101

Change-Id: Ia227903d5efcbda8a955920e3e4123f22aa17aee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/83/381983/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Developing Murano Packages - 101 ================================Murano provides a very powerful and flexible platform to automate the provisioning, deployment, configuration and lifecycle management of applications in OpenStack clouds. However, the flexibility comes at cost: to manage an application with Murano one has to design and develop special scenarios which will tell Murano how to handle different aspects of application lifecycle. These scenarios are usually called "Murano Applications" or "Murano Packages". It is not hard to build them, but it requires some time to get familiar with Murano's DSL to define these scenarios and to learn the common patterns and best practices. This article provides a basic introductory course of these aspects and aims to be the starting point for the developers willing to learn how to develop Murano Application packages with ease.The course consists of the following parts:#. Creating your first Application Package #. Adding User Interface to your package and other improvements #. Modifying the application to do something useful #. Adding scalability scenarios #. Learning some advanced stuff for production-grade deploymentsBefore you proceed, please ensure that you have an OpenStack cloud (devstack-based will work just fine) and a latest version of Murano deployed. This guide assumes that the reader has a basic knowledge of some programming languages and object-oriented design and is a bit familiar with the scripting languages used to configure Linux servers. Also it would be benficial to be familiar with YAML format: lot's of software configuration tools nowadays use YAML, and Murano is no difference.1. Creating your first Application Package ------------------------------------------ All tutorials on programming languages start with a "Hello, World" example, and since Murano provides its own programming language, this guide will start the same way. Let's do a "Hello, World" application. It will not do anything usefull yet, but will provide you with an understanding of how the things work in Murano. We will add more logic to the package at later stages. Now let's start with the basics:1.1 Creating package manifest ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~So, let's start with creating an empty Murano Package. All packages consist of multiple files (two at least) organized into a special structure. So, let's create a directory somewhere in our file system and set it as our current working directory. This directory will contain our package:.. code-block:: shell $ mkdir HelloWorld $ cd HelloWorldThe main element of the package is its `manifest`. It is a description of the package, telling Murano how to display the package in the catalog. It is defined in a yaml file called ``manifest.yaml`` which should placed right in the main package directory. Let's create this file and open it with any text editor:.. code-block:: shell $ vim manifest.yamlThis file may contain a number of sections (we will take a closer look at some of them later), but the mandatory ones are ``FullName`` and ``Type``.The ``FullName`` should be unique identifier of the package, the name which murano uses to distinguish it among other packages in the catalog. It is very important for this name to be globally unique: if you publish your package and someone adds it to their catalog, there should be no chances that someone else's package has the same name. That's why it is recommended to give your packages Full Names based on the domain you (or the company your work for own). We recommend using "reversed-domain-name" notation, similar to one used in the world of Java development: if the `yourdomain.com` is the domain name you own, you could have named your package ``com.yourdomain.HelloWorld``. This way your package name will not duplicate the name of anybody else, even if they also want to end their package for their on "HelloWorld" - they will have different name prefix.``Type`` may have either of two values: ``Application`` or ``Library``. The former indicates the standard package to deploy application with Murano, the latter — a bundle of reusable scenarios which may be useb by other packages. For our Hello-World example we, obviously, need an ``Application`` type.Enter these values and save the file. You should have something like this: FullName: com.yourdomain.HelloWorld Type: ApplicationThis is the minimum required to start. We'll add more manifest data later. 1.2. Adding a class ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ While `manifests` describes murano package in the catalog, the actual logic of packages is put into `classes`, which are plain YAML files placed into the ``Classes`` directory of the application package. So, let's create a directory to store the logic of our application, then create and edit the file to contain the first class of the package. .. code-block:: shell $ mkdir Classes $ vim Classes/HelloWorld.yaml Murano classes follow standard patterns of object-oriented programming: they define the types of the objects which may be instantiated by Murano. The types are composed of `properties`, defining the data structure of objects, and `methods`, containing the logic which murano execute for them. The types may be `extended`: the exteneded class contains all the methods and properties of the class it extends, or it may override some of them. Let's type in the following YAML to create our first class: Name: com.yourdomain.HelloWorld Extends: io.murano.Application Methods: deploy: Body: - $reporter: $this.find('io.murano.Environment').reporter - $reporter.report($this, "Hello, World!")Let's walk this code line by line and see what this code does. First line is pretty obvious: it states the name of our class, ``com.yourdomain.HelloWorld``. Note that this name matches the name of the package - that's intentional. Although it is not mandatory it is strongly recommended to give the main class of your application package the same name as the package itself.Then, there is an ``Extends`` directive. It says that our class extends (or inherits) another class, called ``io.murano.Application``. That is the base class for all classes which should deploy Applications in Murano. As many other classes it ships with Murano itself, thus it name starts with `io.murano.` prefix: murano.io domain is controlled by Murano development team and noone else should create packages or classes having names in that space.Note that ``Extends`` directive may contain not a single value, but a list. In that case the class we create will inherit multiple base classes. Yes, Murano has multiple inheritance, yay!Now, the ``Methods`` block contain all the logic encapsulated in our class. In this example there is just one method, called ``deploy``. This method is defined in the base class we've just inherited - the ``io.murano.Application``, so here we `override` it. ``Body`` block of the method contains the implementation, the actual logic of the method. It's a list of instruction (note the dash-prefixed lines - that's how YAML defines lists), each executed one by one.There are two instruction statements here. The first one declares a `variable` named ``$reporter`` (yes, all the words prefixed with $ are variables in Murano language) and assigns it a value. Unlike other languages Murano uses colon (``:``) as an assignment operator: this makes it convinient to express murano statements as regular YAML mappings. The expression to the right of the colon is executed and the result value is assigned to a variable to the left of the colon.Let's take a closer look at the right-hand side of the expression in the first statement. It takes a value of a special variable called ``$this`` (which always contains a reference to the current object, i.e. the instance of our class for which the method was called; it is same as `self` in python or `this` in Java) and calls a method named ``find`` on it with a string parameter equal to 'io.murano.Environment'; from the call result it takes a "reporter" attribute; this value is assigned to the variable of the left-hand side of the expression. The meaning of this code is simple: it `finds` the object of class 'io.murano.Environment' which owns the current application and returns its "reporter" object. This ``io.murano.Environment`` is a special object which groups multiple deployed applications. When the end-user interact with Murano they create the Environments and place applications into it. So, every Application is able to get a reference to this object by calling ``find`` method like we just did. Meanwhile, the ``io.murano.Environment`` class has various methods to interact with the "outer world", for example to report the end-user with some messages into the deployment log: this is done by the "reporter" property of that class. So, our first statement just retrieved that reporter. The second one uses it to display a message to a user: it calls a method "report", passes the reference to a reporting object and a message as the arguments of the method. Note, that the second statement is not a YAML-mapping: it does not have a colon inside. That's because this statement just makes a method call, it does not need to remember the result.That's it: we've just made a class which greetes the user with a traditional "Hello, World!" message. Now we need to include this class into the package we are creating. Although it is placed within a ``Classes`` subdirectory of the package, it still needs to be explicitly added to the package. To do that, add a ``Classes`` section to your manifest.yaml file. This should be a YAML mapping, having class names as keys and relative paths of files within the ``Classes`` directory as the values. So, for our example class it should look like this: Classes: com.yourdomain.HelloWorld: HelloWorld.yamlPaste this block anywhere in the ``manifest.yaml``1.3. Pack and upload your app ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Our application is ready. It's very simplistic and lacks many features required for real-world applications, but it already can be deployed into Murano and run therer. To do that we need to pack it first. We use good old zip for it. That's it: just zip everything inside your package directory into a zip archive, and you'll get a ready-to-use Murano package:.. code-block:: shell $ zip -r hello_world.zip *This will add all the contents of our package directory to a zip archive called ``hello_world.zip``. Do not forget the ``-r`` argument to include the files in subdirectories (the class file in our case).Now, let's upload the package to murano. Ensure that your system has a murano-client installed and your openstack cloud credentials are expoted as environmnet variables (if not, sourcing an `openrc` file, downloadable from your horizon dashboard will do the latter). Then execute the following command:.. code-block:: shell $ murano package-import ./hello_world.zip Importing package com.yourdomain.MyCoolPackage +----------------------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------+-----------+--------+-----------+-------------+---------+ | ID | Name | FQN | Author | Active | Is Public | Type | Version | +----------------------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------+-----------+--------+-----------+-------------+---------+ | 251a409645d1444aa1ead8eaac451a1d | com.yourdomain.HelloWorld | com.yourdomain.HelloWorld | OpenStack | True | | Application | | +----------------------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------+-----------+--------+-----------+-------------+---------+As you may see from the output, the package has been updated to Murano catalog and is now available there. Let's now deploy it1.4. Deploying your application ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~To deploy an application with Murano one needs to create an `Environment` and add configured instances of your aplications into it. It may be done either with the help of user interface (but that requires some extra efforts from package developer) or by providing an explicit json, describing the exect application instance and its configuration. Let's do the later option for now.First, let's create a json snippet for our application. Since the app is very basic, the snippet is simple as well:.. code-block:: json [ { "op": "add", "path": "/-", "value": { "?": { "name": "Demo", "type": "com.yourdomain.HelloWorld", "id": "42" } } } ]This json follows a standard json-patch notation, i.e. it defines a number of operations to edit a large json document. This particular one `adds` (note the value of ``op`` key) an object descibed in the ``value`` of the json to the `root` (note the ``path`` equal to ``/-`` - that's root) of our environment. The object we add has the `type` of ``com.yourdomain.HelloWorld`` - that's the class we just created two steps ago. Other keys in this json parameterize the object we create: they add a `name` and an `id` to the object. Id is mandatory, name is optional. Note that since the id, name and type are the `system properties` of our object, they are defined in a special section of the json - the so-called `?-header`. Non-system properties, if they existed, would be defined at a top-level of the object. We'll add them in a next chapter to see how they work.For now, save this json to some local file (say, ``input.json``) and let's finally deploy the thing.Execute the following sequence of commands:.. code-block:: shell $ murano environment-create TestHello +----------------------------------+-----------+--------+---------------------+---------------------+ | ID | Name | Status | Created | Updated | +----------------------------------+-----------+--------+---------------------+---------------------+ | 34bf673a26a8439d906827dea328c99c | TestHello | ready | 2016-10-04T13:19:12 | 2016-10-04T13:19:12 | +----------------------------------+-----------+--------+---------------------+---------------------+ $ murano environment-session-create 34bf673a26a8439d906827dea328c99c Created new session: +----------+----------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +----------+----------------------------------+ | id | 6d4a8fa2a5f4484fbc07740ef3ab60dd | +----------+----------------------------------+ $ murano environment-apps-edit --session-id 6d4a8fa2a5f4484fbc07740ef3ab60dd 34bf673a26a8439d906827dea328c99c ./input.jsonThis first command creates a murano environment named ``TestHello``. Note the `id` of the created environment - we use it to reference it in subsequent operations.The second command creates a "configuration session" for this environment. Configuration sessions allow to edit environments in transactional isloated manner. Note the `id` of the created sessions: all subsequent calls to modify or deploy the environment use both ids of environment and session.The third command applies the json-patch we've created before to our environment within the configuration session we created.Now, let's deploy the changes we made:.. code-block:: shell $ murano environment-deploy --session-id 6d4a8fa2a5f4484fbc07740ef3ab60dd 34bf673a26a8439d906827dea328c99c +------------------+---------------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +------------------+---------------------------------------------+ | acquired_by | 7b0fe7c67ede443da9840adb2d518d5c | | created | 2016-10-04T13:39:34 | | description_text | | | id | f700b02e90644ee8ac143781898be833 | | name | TestHello | | services | [ | | | { | | | "?": { | | | "name": "Demo", | | | "status": "deploying", | | | "type": "com.yourdomain.HelloWorld", | | | "id": "42" | | | } | | | } | | | ] | | status | deploying | | tenant_id | 60b7b5f7d4e64ff0b1c5f047d694d7ca | | updated | 2016-10-04T13:39:34 | | version | 0 | +------------------+---------------------------------------------+This will deploy the environment. You may check for its status by executing the following command:.. code-block:: shell $ murano environment-show f700b02e90644ee8ac143781898be833 +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | acquired_by | None | | created | 2016-10-04T13:39:34 | | description_text | | | id | f700b02e90644ee8ac143781898be833 | | name | TestHello | | services | [ | | | { | | | "?": { | | | "status": "ready", | | | "name": "Demo", | | | "type": "com.yourdomain.HelloWorld/0.0.0@com.yourdomain.HelloWorld", | | | "_actions": {}, | | | "id": "42", | | | "metadata": null | | | } | | | } | | | ] | | status | ready | | tenant_id | 60b7b5f7d4e64ff0b1c5f047d694d7ca | | updated | 2016-10-04T13:40:29 | | version | 1 | +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+As you may see, the status of the Environment has changed to ``ready``: it means that the application has been deployed. Open Murano Dashboard, navigate to Environment list and browse the contents of the ``TestHello`` environment there. You'll see that the 'Last Operation' column near the "Demo" component says "Hello, World!" - that's the reporting made by our application:
deleted_lines: ============ Step-by-Step ============The goal of this manual is to walk you through the steps that should be taken while composing an application package to get it ready for uploading to Murano.This tutorial uses a demo application named ApacheHTTPServer to demonstrate how you can create your own Murano application from scratch. We will walk you through its source code and explain how to upload it.ApacheHTTPServer is a simple Murano application that spawns a virtual machine and installs Apache HTTP Server on it. It may also install php if a user wants to.The source code of ApacheHTTPServer is available at `github <https://github.com/openstack/murano-apps/tree/master/ApacheHTTPServer/package>`_. ApacheHTTPServer's source code is written in MuranoPL. This programming language is object-oriented, and we will see classes, objects and object instances. The detailed explanation of its syntax can be found in the :ref:`MuranoPL reference <murano-pl>`. .. warning:: Before you start the Murano application creation process, please consider the :ref:`System prerequisites <system_prerequisites>` and :ref:`Lab requirements <lab_requirements>` in order you do not risk starting with a wrong environment.. toctree:: :maxdepth: 2Step 1. Create the structure of the package ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~You should structure an application package very neatly in order the application could be managed and deployed in the catalog successfully.The package structure of ApacheHTTPServer package is:: .. |_ Classes | |_ ApacheHttpServer.yaml | |_ Resources | |_ scripts | |_runApacheDeploy.sh | |_ DeployApache.template | |_ UI | |_ ui.yaml | |_ logo.png | |_ manifest.yaml The detailed information regarding the package structure can be found in the :ref:`Murano packages <murano-packages>` section.Step 2. Create the manifest file ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~The application manifest file contains general application metadata. It is an entry-point for each Murano application, and is very similar to the manifest of a jar archive. It has a fixed format based on YAML.The ApacheHTTPServer's manifest file:.. code-block:: yaml :linenos: Format: 1.0 Type: Application FullName: com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer Name: Apache HTTP Server Description: | The Apache HTTP Server Project is an effort to develop and maintain an open-source HTTP server for modern operating systems including UNIX and Windows NT. ... Author: Mirantis, Inc Tags: [HTTP, Server, WebServer, HTML, Apache] Classes: com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer: ApacheHttpServer.yamlNow, let's inspect ``manifest.yaml`` line-by-line.Format ------Specifies the version of the format for manifest.yaml to track the syntax changes. Format key presents in each manifest file. Currently, available versions are: `1.0`, `1.1`, `1.2` and `1.3`. For more information, refer to :ref:`format documentation<ManifestFormat>`. Format: 1.0Type ----Specifies the type of the package: Type: Application.. note:: ``Application`` starts with the capital letter. This is the naming convention for all the pre-defined values in Murano code.FullName --------Stands for the unique service application name. That name allows to easily recognize to which scope an application belongs. All other applications can address to the Apache application methods by this name.To ensure the global uniqueness, the same naming convention as the naming convention of Java packages and classes is followed.The examples of such class names may include:* ``com.example.Foo`` - for demo applications and packages* ``org.openstack.projectName.Foo`` - for applications and packages developed and maintained by the teams of official OpenStack projects* ``com.companyname.Foo`` - for applications and packages developed and maintained by a third party controlling the "companyname.com" domain name* ``io.murano.Foo`` - for applications and packages developed and maintained by the core murano team as part of the murano project. So, io.murano is a preferred alias for longer ``org.openstack.murano`` FQN prefix.In the following example the ``com.example.apache.`` part is the "package" part of the name, while ``ApacheHttpServer`` stands for the "class" part of the name: FullName: com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServerName ----Stands for the display name of the application. You will be able to reset a display name when you upload ApacheHTTPServer package to Murano:.. code-block:: yaml Name: Apache HTTP ServerDescription -----------Contains the application description rendered under the application title:.. code-block:: yaml :linenos: Description: | The Apache HTTP Server Project is an effort to develop and maintain an open-source HTTP server for modern operating systems including UNIX and Windows NT. The goal of this project is to provide a secure, efficient and extensible server that provides HTTP services in sync with the current HTTP standards. Apache httpd has been the most popular web server on the Internet since April 1996, and celebrated its 17th birthday as a project this February.Let's take a closer look at the syntax:The vertical line ``|`` symbol comes from YAML syntax. The ``>`` symbol can be used interchangeably. These are the `YAML block style indicators <http://yaml.org/spec/current.html#id2537921>`_, which mean that all the leading indents and new line symbols should be preserved. This is very useful for long, multi-line descriptions, because this affects how they are displayed on the UI... warning:: Avoid tab symbols inside YAML files. If YAML contains the tab symbol, it will not be parsed correctly. The error message may be cryptic or misleading. We recommend that you check the YAML syntax before composing the application package using any of the available online tools.Author ------Contains the name of the author of an application, it is only displayed in the application details and does not affect anything... code-block:: yaml Author: Mirantis, Inc.. note:: Single quotes usage is optional here: ``Author: 'Mirantis, Inc'``, thus they are omitted in the code extract below.Tags ----Is an array of tags. You can search an application by its tag. You may want to specify several tags for one application:.. code-block:: yaml Tags: [HTTP, Server, WebServer, HTML, Apache]Besides, YAML allows tag specification using another syntax, which is an equivalent to the one given above:.. code-block:: yaml Tags: - HTTP - Server - WebServer - HTML - ApacheClasses -------Is a mapping between all classes present in ApacheHttpServer application and the file names where these classes are defined in. This is one-to-one relationship, which means that there is one and the only class per a single file.The line ``com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer: ApacheHttpServer.yaml`` says that the class ``com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer`` is defined in the file ``ApacheHttpServer.yaml``:.. code-block:: yaml Classes: com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer: ApacheHttpServer.yaml Step 3. Create the execution plan template ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The execution plan template contains the instructions understandable to the murano agent on what should be executed to deploy an application. It is the file with the ``.template`` extension located in the ``/APP_NAME/Resources`` directory. The ApacheHTTPServer's DeployApache.template: .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: FormatVersion: 2.0.0 Version: 1.0.0 Name: Deploy Apache Parameters: enablePHP: $enablePHP Body: | return apacheDeploy('{0}'.format(args.enablePHP)).stdout Scripts: apacheDeploy: Type: Application Version: 1.0.0 EntryPoint: runApacheDeploy.sh Files: [] Options: captureStdout: true captureStderr: true As it can be viewed from the source code, besides specifying versions of different items, ApacheHTTPServer execution plan accepts the ``enablePHP`` parameter. This parameter is an input parameter to the ``apacheDeploy.sh`` script. This script initiates ``runApacheDeploy.sh`` execution, which is also located at the ``Resources`` directory and installs apache app and php if selected. For the detailed information regarding the execution plan template, its sections and syntax, please refer to the :ref:`Execution plan template <exec_plan>`. Step 4. Create the dynamic UI form definition ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ApacheHTTPServer's ui.yaml source code: .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: Version: 2 Application: ?: type: com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer name: $.appConfiguration.name enablePHP: $.appConfiguration.enablePHP instance: ?: type: io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance name: generateHostname($.instanceConfiguration.unitNamingPattern, 1) flavor: $.instanceConfiguration.flavor image: $.instanceConfiguration.osImage keyname: $.instanceConfiguration.keyPair availabilityZone: $.instanceConfiguration.availabilityZone assignFloatingIp: $.appConfiguration.assignFloatingIP Forms: - appConfiguration: fields: - name: license type: string description: Apache License, Version 2.0 hidden: true required: false - name: name type: string label: Application Name initial: 'ApacheHttpServer' description: >- Enter a desired name for the application. Just A-Z, a-z, 0-9, dash and underline are allowed - name: enablePHP label: Enable PHP type: boolean description: >- Add php support to the Apache WebServer initial: false required: false widgetMedia: css: {all: ['muranodashboard/css/checkbox.css']} - name: assignFloatingIP type: boolean label: Assign Floating IP description: >- Select to true to assign floating IP automatically initial: false required: false widgetMedia: css: {all: ['muranodashboard/css/checkbox.css']} - name: dcInstances type: integer hidden: true initial: 1 ... Now, let's inspect it line-by-line. Application ----------- Defines the object model by which engine deploys the ApacheHTTPServer application, and includes YAQL expressions. The section contains the reference to the Apache class, the one that is provided in the manifest, named with the `?` symbol. This indicates system information: .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: Application: ?: type: com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer For ApacheHTTPServer application it is defined that the user should input the application name, some instance parameters and decide whether PHP should be enabled or not: .. code-block:: yaml enablePHP: $.appConfiguration.enablePHP The `instance` section assumes that the value, entered by the user in the first form named ``appConfiguration`` is stored in an application object module. The same applies for the instance parameter. Providing the question mark with the defined type ``io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance`` indicates an instance of MuranoPl object. .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: instance: ?: type: io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance .. note:: This parameter is named ``instance`` here because its class definition property has the ``instance`` name. You can specify any name in the :ref:`class definition file <step_5_class_definition>`, and then use it in the UI form definition. Forms ----- Contains UI forms prototypes that are merged to the application creation wizard. Each form field will be translated to the Django field and most of the parameters correspond to parameters in the Django form field. All fields are required by default. Hidden fields are used to print extra information in the form description. After the upload, the section content will be browsed on the left side of the form and its description on the right. Please take a look at the :guilabel:`Configure Application: Apache HTTP Server` dialog: .. image:: step_1.png .. note:: The :guilabel:`assignFloatingIP` and :guilabel:`enablePHP` boolean fields are shown as checkboxes. Here is how the second dialog looks like: .. image:: step_2.png For more information about Dynamic UI, please refer to :ref:`the main reference <DynamicUISpec>`. .. _step_5_class_definition: Step 5: Define MuranoPL class definitions ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ All application classes are located in the ``Classes`` folder. As ApacheHttpServer uses only one class, just one file can be found in this directory. Here is how it looks like: .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: Namespaces: =: com.example.apache std: io.murano res: io.murano.resources sys: io.murano.system Name: ApacheHttpServer Extends: std:Application Properties: name: Contract: $.string().notNull() enablePHP: Contract: $.bool() Default: false instance: Contract: $.class(res:Instance).notNull() Methods: initialize: Body: - $._environment: $.find(std:Environment).require() deploy: Body: - If: not $.getAttr(deployed, false) Then: - $._environment.reporter.report($this, 'Creating VM for Apache Server.') - $securityGroupIngress: ... - $._environment.securityGroupManager.addGroupIngress($securityGroupIngress) - $.instance.deploy() - $resources: new(sys:Resources) - $template: $resources.yaml('DeployApache.template').bind(dict(enablePHP => $.enablePHP)) - $._environment.reporter.report($this, 'Instance is created. Deploying Apache') - $.instance.agent.call($template, $resources) - $._environment.reporter.report($this, 'Apache is installed.') - $.setAttr(deployed, true) Now, let's inspect it line-by-line. Namespaces ---------- Can be named *shortcuts* since this is an additional section which enables short names instead of the long ones: .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: Namespaces: =: com.example.apache std: io.murano res: io.murano.resources sys: io.murano.system .. note:: ``=:`` refers to the *current* namespace Name ---- Contains the class name that is defined in this file. So full class name will be current namespace and name, provided by corresponding key: ``com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer``: .. code-block:: yaml Name: ApacheHttpServer .. note:: One .yaml file should contain only one class definition. Extends ------- Determines inheritance, and ``io.murano.Application`` should be a parent for all the murano applications. This class has defined deploy method and only instances of that class can be used in Environment class. Environment class, in its turn, is responsible for the deployment configurations. Definition of both classes are located at meta/io.murano folder of murano repository. Thus, if you want to have some modifications of ApacheHttpServer, you can set com.example.apache.ApacheHttpServer in the Extends section of a new Application class: .. code-block:: yaml Extends: std:Application Properties ---------- Defines the dictionary. Apache HTTP Server application has three properties: ``name``, ``enablePHP`` and ``instance``. For each of them certain ``Contract`` is defined. Only ``enablePHP`` is optional, and its default value equals to ``false``. ``Instance`` is the required parameter and should be an instance of the predefined in core library ``io.murano.resources.Instance`` class. Methods ------- The ``initialize`` method is like ``__init__`` in Python, and executes together with properties initialization. It accesses the environment, which the application belongs to, and is used only for sending reports about the deployment state. Private variable ``_environment`` is defined as follows: .. code-block:: yaml :linenos: initialize: Body: - $._environment: $.find(std:Environment).require() The ``deploy`` method sets up instance spawning and configuration. This method should be executed only once. So in the first order deployed variable is checked to be false in the current scope. It performs the following actions: * configures securityGroups; * initiates new virtual machine spawning: ``$.instance.deploy()`` * loads the execution plan template, located in the ``Resources`` directory to the instance of resources class: ``$resources.yaml('DeployApache.template')`` * updates the plan with parameters taken from the user: ``bind(dict(enablePHP => $.enablePHP))`` * sends ready-to-execute-plan to murano agent: ``$.instance.agent.call($template, $resources)`` Step 6. Add the application logo (optional) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Download or create your own ``.png`` image associated with your application. The recommended size is 70x70 px, and the square shape is preferable. There are no limits regarding the image filename. In Apache HTTP Server we use the default name ``logo.png``: .. image:: logo.png Step 7. Compose a zip archive ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Select all the files prepared for the package and create an archive in zip format. If the command is executed from the console, do not forget to add the ``-r`` option to include all the attachments. .. note:: The manifest file should not contain the root folder. In other words, the manifest should be located in the archive root directory. | **Congratulations! Your application is ready to be uploaded to the application catalog.** .. TODO: add links to "How to upload a package" (OG)

subject: Harmonize notification configuration

commit_message:
Harmonize notification configuration

This change makes the configuration of notifications consistent across
Liberty, Mitaka and Newton releases.

It also aligns the configuration between the controller and volume roles
by allowing to define the notitication topic(s) and messaging driver.

Finally it preserves backward-compatibility when the 'notification' parameter
is a boolean value instead of a dict.

Change-Id: Ib135f4274c251c314377ff6be915480cd2e543cc

commit_message:
Add destroy_after_deletion param when cluster del nodes.

destroy nodes after delete from cluster when destroy_after_
deletion is True, otherwise, just remove thses nodes from
cluster and keep them alive.

Change-Id: I47be91b3a661638226c631c7e9498e91b57ce07a
Depends-On: Ib1207dd12b3b11814e6ab4608eb4810de0cb7d11

commit_message:
Enable and start docker service when install docker

If the docker service is stop, chmod /var/run/docker.sock will have error:
chmod: cannot access '/var/run/docker.sock': No such file or directory

we should enable and start docker service when install docker.

Change-Id: I2a582e48522c41943de06fc57265f9a2fa7b76bd
(cherry picked from commit 387abc937516766964f7da791bf302302d42d917)

commit_message:
Add port update operation support(1)

1. What is the problem
Tricircle does not support port update operation now.

2. What is the solution to the problem
Implement related functions

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
Add name,description,admin_state_up, extra_dhcp_opts, device_owner,
device_id, mac_address attribute updates supported,
where updating name only takes effect on the central pod.

Change-Id: I91621474fc4d003dcd224bbe68f15955b7756e9c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/82/415382/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if mac_change and orig_port['binding:vif_type'] not in unplugged_types: vif_type=orig_port['binding:vif_type'], old_mac=orig_port['mac_address'], new_mac=port['mac_address']) def _filter_non_supported_attrs(self, port_data): supported_attrs = ['description', 'admin_state_up', 'extra_dhcp_opts', 'device_owner', 'device_id', 'mac_address', 'name'] for key in port_data.keys(): if key not in supported_attrs: port_data.pop(key) if mappings: with context.session.begin(): b_pod, b_port_id = mappings[0] b_pod_name = b_pod['pod_name'] b_client = self._get_client(pod_name=b_pod_name) b_port = b_client.get_ports(context, b_port_id) self._check_mac_update_allowed( b_port, port[attributes.PORT]) port_data = port[attributes.PORT] self._filter_non_supported_attrs(port_data) res = super(TricirclePlugin, self).update_port( context, port_id, port) # name is not allowed to be updated, because it is used by # lock_handle to retrieve bottom/local resources that have # been created but not registered in the resource routing # table if 'name' in port_data: port_data.pop('name') try: b_client.update_ports(t_ctx, b_port_id, port) except q_cli_exceptions.NotFound: LOG.error( _LE('port: %(port_id)s not found, ' 'pod name: %(name)s'), {'net_id': b_port_id, 'name': b_pod_name}) else: self._filter_non_supported_attrs(port[attributes.PORT])
deleted_lines: if mac_change and orig_port.vif_type not in unplugged_types: vif_type=orig_port.vif_type, old_mac=orig_port['mac_address'], new_mac=port['mac_address']) for mapping in mappings: pod_name = mapping[0]['pod_name'] b_port_id = mapping[1] b_client = self._get_client(pod_name=pod_name) b_port = b_client.get_ports(context, b_port_id) self._check_mac_update_allowed(b_port, port) with context.session.begin(): if mappings: self.xjob_handler.update_port( t_ctx, port_id, t_constants.POD_NOT_SPECIFIED)

Add port update

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/81/415381/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.extensions import portbindings def _check_mac_update_allowed(self, orig_port, port): unplugged_types = (portbindings.VIF_TYPE_BINDING_FAILED, portbindings.VIF_TYPE_UNBOUND) new_mac = port.get('mac_address') mac_change = (new_mac is not None and orig_port['mac_address'] != new_mac) if mac_change and orig_port.vif_type not in unplugged_types: raise exceptions.PortBound(port_id=orig_port['id'], vif_type=orig_port.vif_type, old_mac=orig_port['mac_address'], new_mac=port['mac_address']) def update_port(self, context, port_id, port): t_ctx = t_context.get_context_from_neutron_context(context) res = super(TricirclePlugin, self).update_port(context, port_id, port) # update top port and trigger asynchronous job via RPC to update bottom # port else: mappings = db_api.get_bottom_mappings_by_top_id( t_ctx, port_id, t_constants.RT_PORT) for mapping in mappings: pod_name = mapping[0]['pod_name'] b_port_id = mapping[1] b_client = self._get_client(pod_name=pod_name) b_port = b_client.get_ports(context, b_port_id) self._check_mac_update_allowed(b_port, port) with context.session.begin(): res = super(TricirclePlugin, self).update_port( context, port_id, port) if mappings: self.xjob_handler.update_port( t_ctx, port_id, t_constants.POD_NOT_SPECIFIED)
deleted_lines: def update_port(self, context, port_id, port): # TODO(zhiyuan) handle bottom port update res = super(TricirclePlugin, self).update_port(context, port_id, port) t_ctx = t_context.get_context_from_neutron_context(context)

// }, 'Test restrictions for Bonds': function() { var itfConfigure = 'button.btn-configure-interfaces'; var bondCheckbox = 'input[type="checkbox"][name="attribute_checkbox"]'; var bondText = 'input[type="text"][name="attribute_text"]'; return this.remote .updatePlugin('update_bonds bond_restrict') .newClusterWithPlugin(modal) // Add one node, open interface configuration .then(function() { return common.addNodesToCluster(1, ['Controller']); }) .selectNodeByIndex(0) .clickByCssSelector(itfConfigure) // Bond several interfaces and save changes .bondInterfaces(-1, -2) .assertElementExists('input[label="bond0"]', 'Bonds was not created') .applyItfChanges() // Check that Checkbox is visible, but Text-input isn't .selectPluginNICPropertyByIndex(0).sleep(1000) .clickByCssSelector(bondCheckbox) .assertElementNotExists(bondText, 'Text-input field is displayed') // Enable KVM .clickByCssSelector('a.settings.cluster-tab') .clickByCssSelector('button.btn-danger.proceed-btn') // Discard changes .then(function() { return modal.waitToClose(); }) .clickByCssSelector('a.subtab-link-compute') .clickByCssSelector('input[name="libvirt_type"][value="kvm"]') .clickByCssSelector('button.btn-apply-changes') .waitForCssSelector('.btn-load-defaults:not(:disabled)', 1000) // Verify that text input is displayed .then(function() { return clusterPage.goToTab('Nodes'); }) .clickByCssSelector(itfConfigure) .selectPluginNICPropertyByIndex(0) .assertElementExists(bondCheckbox, 'Checkbox is not displayed') .assertElementExists(bondText, 'Text-input field is not displayed'); }, }; }); });

Second, while looking into 1650816, I stumbled upon 1650888 which is

commit_message:
trove pylint cleanup(s)

This commit includes two cleanups in trove-pylint.

First, the deprecation warning is because the text.ParseableOutputFormat is
being deprecated[1] and produces a deprecation warning as shown in the
bug.

Second, while looking into 1650816, I stumbled upon 1650888 which is
also fixed. A block of code was wrongly indented and when I disabled
"-E" to generate warnings, produced a crash in pylint. If the line
generated doesn't match the regular expression, the various parameters
to the next call (to ignore()) are not set and you get unbound
variable errors.

[1] https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/blob/master/pylint/reporters/text.py#L163

Change-Id: I43bd6569a98eeb1b326e4a0ca1addaf97c0830a5
Closes-Bug: #1650530
Closes-But: #1650888
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/85/411785/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ParseableTextReporter(text.TextReporter): name = 'parseable' line_format = '{path}:{line}: [{msg_id}({symbol}), {obj}] {msg}' # that's it folks reporter = ParseableTextReporter(output=buffer)

commit_message:
Show team and repo badges on README

This patch adds the team's and repository's badges to the README file.
The motivation behind this is to communicate the project status and
features at first glance.

For more information about this effort, please read this email thread:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-October/105562.html

To see an example of how this would look like check:

b'https://gist.github.com/9e9e2e2ba4ecfdece7827082114f8258\n'

Change-Id: Ieaa9772d966d441fb7d0197f42f55b3de6419ff8
Partial-Bug: 1644851

commit_message:
get rid of a couple of old oslo-incubator object references

Found these while looking around the rpc message code; these paths are
no longer valid. Didn't want to combine this change with the one to
add signing/verification as it appears to be more of a cleanup thing.

TRANSPORT_ALIASES is no longer used so I've got rid of that as well.

Change-Id: I398f1286bcb08740a6125d4e773c9de6708e1d43

commit_message:
Use mariadb.cnf for mariadb custom file name

galera.cnf is weird and does respect the /etc/kolla/config/<service>
roles. Leave galera.cnf for back compatible. Add mariadb.cnf for better
use.

Closes-Bug: #1632191
Change-Id: I39efef6c3702118b7373a7e8e32d35e52861acbb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/38/399038/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(Jeffrey4l): mariadb.cnf file is expected custom filename. galera.cnf # file is for backward compatible. - name: Copying over galera.cnf and mariadb.cnf - "{{ node_custom_config }}/mariadb.cnf" - "{{ node_custom_config }}/mariadb/{{ inventory_hostname }}/mariadb.cnf"

commit_message:
Readd networking-l2gw to the list of bot managed project

The project used to be in the neutron governance but it
is far from being retired or on its way to being defunct.

commit_message:
Use magic constants instead of magic numbers

It's a best practice to use magic constants instead of
magic numbers. So, this patch tried to introduce the
HTTP status codes unified by the httplib to replace
the direct hard code.

Change-Id: I50204008961eedd9b7574bd9ea4ec8d315da4734
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/23/290323/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Wait for server to be active before deleting
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-27 07:08:14.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/api/compute/servers/test_servers_negative.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/be590a7001e30a8108b89d45576ee4d7c8a5c77b', 'message': 'Wait for server to be active before deleting

As in Iab6b4fef58c32d110f9454e49b4d7be8c9053fb6, there is still
one occurrence of deleting server without waiting for it to be
active (And I think this is the last one, sorry to miss it in
previous patch).
Deleting a server immediately when it is spawning will sometimes
result in ERROR status and is not deleted, since the testcase
only wants a deleted server, we can wait for server to be active
before deleting to ensure the server be deleted successully.

Change-Id: I008b68a927581288a411ba756b0b28a77e9fbe0d
'}]
commit_message:
Wait for server to be active before deleting

As in Iab6b4fef58c32d110f9454e49b4d7be8c9053fb6, there is still
one occurrence of deleting server without waiting for it to be
active (And I think this is the last one, sorry to miss it in
previous patch).
Deleting a server immediately when it is spawning will sometimes
result in ERROR status and is not deleted, since the testcase
only wants a deleted server, we can wait for server to be active
before deleting to ensure the server be deleted successully.

Change-Id: I008b68a927581288a411ba756b0b28a77e9fbe0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/23/415123/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use _show_resource() of super class

There is no need to override the method _show_resource()
for monasca resources, use the implementation of
Resource class.
Notes: Monascaclient has provided the to_dict() method already.

Change-Id: Ia120544ac017fc27e5cf63ccea1742192b021aa5

commit_message:
Use uuid instead of container_id in _validate_container_state

In the function _validate_container_state, checks the status
of zun_container. So I think it's better to show the uuid of
container in the exception messages instead of container_id
which is generated by docker.

Change-Id: I8894d7aa4b3f4b957483af0865cdae70caffb548
Closes-Bug: #1652210

commit_message:
Remove the usage of MagnumObjectDictCompat from certificate

Nova has removed the usage of NovaObjectDictCompat:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/rm-object-dict-compat.
magnum needs a similar cleanup.

Partially-Implements: blueprint rm-object-dict-compat

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-26 04:26:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum-ui/commit/fb9a9cdd02c3d067e3e99505a83b4d1bfb01d5cb', 'message': 'Set reasonable name to browser title bar

commit_message:
Set reasonable name to browser title bar

Currently, when using anuglar table, the name of title bar on
browser is always "Horizon - OpenStack Dashboard".
It's not good at point of view of usability.
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: I73c5077058d4214b20116577759ea2d5b96742cc
Closes-Bug: #1647855

commit_message:
Add OS::Sahara::Job resource

Patch added new resource OS::Sahara::Job for managing job
resource of Sahara service. It allows to execute job with
sending signal to resoruce, using corresponding url attribute
or with heat API signal call.

Co-Authored-By: Dmitriy Uvarenkov <duvarenkov@mirantis.com>,
                Peter Razumovsky <prazumovsky@mirantis.com>
blueprint sahara-edp
Change-Id: Ieeeaaead9e2ff67ac6511640322ac91933dde265
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/80/231080/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from heat.common.i18n import _ from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine import support # NOTE(tlashchova): copied from sahara/utils/api_validator.py SAHARA_NAME_REGEX = r"^[a-zA-Z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9\-_\.]*$" class SaharaJob(resource.Resource): """A resource for creating sahara job. A job specifies the type of the job and lists all of the individual job binary objects. Can be launched using resource-signal. """ support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='6.0.0') PROPERTIES = ( NAME, TYPE, MAINS, LIBS, DESCRIPTION, INTERFACE ) = ( 'name', 'type', 'mains', 'libs', 'description', 'interface' ) _INTERFACE_KEYS = ( INTERFACE_NAME, INTERFACE_DESCRIPTION, MAPPING_TYPE, LOCATION, VALUE_TYPE, REQUIRED, DEFAULT ) = ( 'name', 'description', 'mapping_type', 'location', 'value_type', 'required', 'default' ) _MAPPING_TYPES = ( ARGS, CONFIGS, PARAMS ) = ( 'args', 'configs', 'params' ) _VALUE_TYPES = ( STRING, NUMBER, DATA_SOURCE ) = ( 'string', 'number', 'data_source' ) ATTRIBUTES = ( EXECUTIONS ) = ( 'executions' ) properties_schema = { NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("Name of the job."), constraints=[ constraints.Length(min=1, max=50), constraints.AllowedPattern(SAHARA_NAME_REGEX), ], ), TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("Type of the job."), required=True ), MAINS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _("IDs of job's main job binaries."), schema=properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING ), default=[] ), LIBS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _("IDs of job's lib job binaries"), schema=properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING ), default=[] ), DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Description of the job.'), default='' ), INTERFACE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _(''), schema=properties.Schema( properties.Schema.MAP, schema={ INTERFACE_NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _(''), required=True ), INTERFACE_DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('') ), MAPPING_TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _(''), constraints=[ constraints.AllowedValues(_MAPPING_TYPES), ], required=True ), LOCATION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _(''), required=True ), VALUE_TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _(''), constraints=[ constraints.AllowedValues(_VALUE_TYPES), ] ), REQUIRED: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.BOOLEAN, _(''), required=True ), DEFAULT: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _(''), ) } ), ) } default_client_name = 'sahara' entity = 'jobs' def _job_name(self): return self.properties[self.NAME] or self.physical_resource_name() def handle_create(self): args = { 'name': self._job_name(), 'type': self.properties[self.TYPE], 'mains': self.properties[self.MAINS], 'libs': self.properties[self.LIBS], 'description': self.properties[self.DESCRIPTION], 'interface': self.properties[self.INTERFACE] } job = self.client().jobs.create(**args) self.resource_id_set(job.id) def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Sahara::Job': SaharaJob }

Remove mox in tests/unit/objects/test_instance_info_cache

This patch replaces mox with mock in
tests/unit/objects/test_instance_info_cache

Partially-Implements: blueprint remove-mox-ocata

Change-Id: I6e2a86bd6641144e19d45fca996ce6beef1a3c59

added_lines: from nova import test @mock.patch.object(db, 'instance_info_cache_get') def test_get_by_instance_uuid(self, get_mock): get_mock.return_value = dict(fake_info_cache, network_info=nwinfo.json()) @mock.patch.object(db, 'instance_info_cache_get') def test_get_by_instance_uuid_no_entries(self, get_mock): get_mock.return_value = None with test.nested( mock.patch.object(db, 'instance_info_cache_update'), mock.patch.object(cells_opts, 'get_cell_type'), mock.patch.object(cells_rpcapi, 'CellsAPI', use_mock_anything=True), mock.patch.object(cells_api, ) as (update_mock, get_mock, rpc_mock, api_mock): nwinfo = network_model.NetworkInfo.hydrate([{'address': 'foo'}]) new_info_cache = fake_info_cache.copy() new_info_cache['network_info'] = nwinfo.json() update_mock.return_value = new_info_cache if update_cells: get_mock.return_value = cell_type if cell_type == 'compute': rpc_mock.return_value = cells_api cells_api.instance_info_cache_update_at_top( self.context, 'foo') @mock.patch.object(db, 'instance_info_cache_get') def test_refresh(self, get_mock): get_mock.return_value = fake_info_cache
deleted_lines: def test_get_by_instance_uuid(self): self.mox.StubOutWithMock(db, 'instance_info_cache_get') db.instance_info_cache_get( self.context, uuids.info_instance).AndReturn( dict(fake_info_cache, network_info=nwinfo.json())) self.mox.ReplayAll() def test_get_by_instance_uuid_no_entries(self): self.mox.StubOutWithMock(db, 'instance_info_cache_get') db.instance_info_cache_get(self.context, uuids.info_instance).AndReturn(None) self.mox.ReplayAll() self.mox.StubOutWithMock(db, 'instance_info_cache_update') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(cells_opts, 'get_cell_type') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(cells_rpcapi, 'CellsAPI', use_mock_anything=True) self.mox.StubOutWithMock(cells_api, nwinfo = network_model.NetworkInfo.hydrate([{'address': 'foo'}]) new_info_cache = fake_info_cache.copy() new_info_cache['network_info'] = nwinfo.json() db.instance_info_cache_update( self.context, uuids.info_instance, {'network_info': nwinfo.json()}).AndReturn(new_info_cache) if update_cells: cells_opts.get_cell_type().AndReturn(cell_type) if cell_type == 'compute': cells_rpcapi.CellsAPI().AndReturn(cells_api) cells_api.instance_info_cache_update_at_top( self.context, 'foo') self.mox.ReplayAll() def test_refresh(self): self.mox.StubOutWithMock(db, 'instance_info_cache_get') db.instance_info_cache_get( self.context, uuids.info_instance_1).AndReturn(fake_info_cache) self.mox.ReplayAll()

String interpolation should be delayed to be handled by the logging code,
rather than being done at the point of the logging call.

"}]
commit_message:
Modify variable's usage in Log Messages

String interpolation should be delayed to be handled by the logging code,
rather than being done at the point of the logging call.
Ref:http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#adding-variables-to-log-messages
For example:
LOG.info(_LI('some message: variable=%s') % variable)
LOG.info(_LI('some message: variable=%s'), variable)

Change-Id: Id51bb1b90fc5cf05e0d81982188d7c738f39d997

Closes-bug: 1484653

commit_message:
Clear ENGINE cache on MySQL password change

Clears the cache of the SQLAlchemy ENGINE variable
when the root password is updated during prepare.
Fixes a race condition where the ENGINE cache would
cache a connection without the password.

Change-Id: I44df5b2a3dc7e4094b81b98fa631426b1a4acc12
Closes-bug: 1484653
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/55/213155/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def clear_engine_cache(): """Clear the cache used by get_engine().""" global ENGINE ENGINE = None clear_engine_cache()

commit_message:
Fix restoring redis data is not ended

Because data type of expected value(string) and current value(int) is different.
Type of expected value chane to integer.

Closes-Bug: #1630460
Change-Id: I29f2e12cc75d4f290bceae2a830910cd00f3537b

commit_message:
Replace functions 'Dict.get' and 'del' with 'Dict.pop'

Refactoring code: Making 'kwargs' to use single instruction: pop()
rather than two instructions: get() and del, giving the codes a
format that carries through.

Closes-Bug: #1571548
Change-Id: If81962c8027442f75d27cb048ab0acdd33311f8c

deleted_lines: kwargs['data'] = json.dumps(kwargs['json']) try: del kwargs['json'] except KeyError: pass

commit_message:
Refactor test_dbaas.py: strings to variables and re-scoping variables

Previously, hardcoded strings were used for a user's information throughout
the test_dbaas.py file. These will be replaced with member variables for
the appropriate classes. Also, variables that were already created in this
fasion are only in the specific functions that need them, and are being
moved to the classes they are used in instead.

Closes-Bug: #1474100
Change-Id: I5277c107ae95b16d3fc555dbdbb4c167c8836fc8

commit_message:
Fix an error about line_terminator

In Linux /n as a newline, and Windows is /r/n, so I will be the
default value is set to/n line_terminator, in fact, the most intuitive
is solved test_operating_system.TestOperatingSystem.test_key_value_file
_codec problem.

before change:http://paste.openstack.org/show/585902/
after change:http://paste.openstack.org/show/586319/

Closes-Bug #1634755

Change-Id: I0f6052b037ab62644b5e036ddf925b7e24636ba5

commit_message:
Cleanup Newton Release Notes

Do not show versions 5.0.0 in the Newton release notes - see
http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/trove/newton.html

This adds the earliest-version directive to only show the Newton release
which was 6.0.0.

Also, do not generate an index file, it is empty, see:
http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/trove/genindex.html

Change-Id: I3435fff9c8c894029012c2d0f8db725bc8a11b74

commit_message:
Extend the cloudinit support for multiple datastore versions

Trove supports datastore cloudinit feature. It was designed to have
single cloudinit file for each datastore and cloudinit file format
was datastore.cloudinit . We can prepare the guestagent with the
support of cloudinit feature by installing specific datastore and
trove-guestagent packages during Trove DB instance creation process.
Trove can support only one version of datastore with current design.

This patch implements datastore version specific cloudinit support.
This allows Trove to provide multiple datastore version support with
cloudinit feature. We need to have the new naming format for the
cloudinit files datastore-version.cloudinit

Example: mysql-5.6.cloudinit

Change-Id: Idc5defa329f5531dc7cd8c6d8ad984dd860aec20
Implements: blueprint data-store-version-cloud-init-support

commit_message:
Add Python 3.5 classifier and venv

Now that there is a passing gate job, we can claim
support for Python 3.5 in the classifier.
This patch also adds the convenience py35 venv.

Change-Id: I5547e8ddbe0abf485a7e4bf1b302884b48d21ce9

commit_message:
Fix nova_proxy_admin* param values in conf files

This patch will correctly configure the nova_proxy_admin*
param values while installing trove using the devstack.

This allows trove-taskmanager to prepare nova admin client
to publish exists notifications.

Change-Id: I00dde06b059aaf5c80213af8798efeebde2aaa94
Closes-Bug: #1635596

commit_message:
Guest-agent metadata

Allowing guest-agents to retrieve critical metadata from the image.

Implements blueprint: guestagent-image-metadata

Change-Id: I11944aff00c74295a46b6d259125ec917b34806b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/00/388100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/juno-template.rst .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None Note: This comment may be removed if desired, however the license notice above should remain. ========================= Guestagent Image Metadata ========================= .. If section numbers are desired, unindent this .. sectnum:: .. If a TOC is desired, unindent this .. contents:: Allowing guest-agents to retrieve critical metadata from the image. Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/guestagent-image-metadata Problem Description =================== Trove guest-agents currently assume the image would have certain critical properties such as system/datastore names and paths set to known values. This design becomes progressively more difficult to maintain as we add more different platforms and datastore versions. The paths and names depend on the platform, datastore version and installation package used. They may also be modified by the image builder at any time to match the user's requirements. It is not always possible for Trove to mandate the expected values and the logic to handle different cases becomes progressively more and more complex with every new platform and datastore version. Proposed Change =============== All properties of the image are known to the image builder. The image builders may also wish to tweak the default values according to their requirements. It would be nearly impossible for Trove to reliably infer all these values. This document suggests introduction of an optional metadata file to the image from which the guests could obtain the required information. Image builders may use this file to communicate the required properties to the guest-agent. The file may not be required (at least for the existing datastore) meaning that Trove would try to fall back to the current defaults in the absence of the metadata file. See POC review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/345533/ Configuration ------------- Optional metadata file on the image. Potentially a Trove configuration property for the path to the metadata file (but see `Alternatives`_) Database -------- None Public API ---------- None Public API Security ------------------- None Python API ---------- None CLI (python-troveclient) ------------------------ None Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- New base guestagent App interface will be introduced. The following interfaces and related properties will be exposed: .. code-block:: python def get_trove_user_name(self, default='trove') # Trove user. [user_name] def get_user_group(self, default='trove') # Trove group. [user_group] def get_datastore_service_name(self, default=None) # Database service name. [service_name] def get_datastore_service_user_name(self, default=None) # Database service owner name. [service_user_name] def get_datastore_service_user_group(self, default=None) # Database service owner group. [service_user_group] def get_datastore_config_dir(self, default=None) # Database base config directory. [config_dir] def get_datastore_data_dir(self, default=None) # Database base data directory. [data_dir] def get_datastore_bin_dir(self, default=None) # Database base bin directory. [bin_dir] def get_datastore_default_superuser_name(self, default=None) # Database default superuser name. [default_user] def get_datastore_default_superuser_password(self, default=None) # Database default superuser password. [default_password] The guestagent will read the properties from the metadata file. If the file does not exist or the property is not defined it falls back to default. The default value may be a scalar or a dict of OS -> value mappings. See the following usage examples: .. code-block:: python @property def service_candidates(self): return [self.get_datastore_service_name(default='cassandra')] @property def cassandra_conf_dir(self): return self.get_datastore_config_dir(default={ operating_system.REDHAT: "/etc/cassandra/default.conf/", operating_system.DEBIAN: "/etc/cassandra/", operating_system.SUSE: "/etc/cassandra/default.conf/" }) The mappings are the same as the ones currently used by the existing guests. The conversion of the existing code should be relativelly straightforward. The hard-coded values would be replaced by base properties with the current value as default. Alternatives ------------ The metadata file location may also be provided together with other configuration files on the Trove guest start command-line. Dashboard Impact (UX) ===================== None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Petr Malik <pmalik@tesora.com> Milestones ---------- Ocata-1 Work Items ---------- - Introduce the base guest App interface. - Inherit all existing guest Apps from the above base. - Update the existing guest implementations one-by-one to read from the metadata file where appropriate. Upgrade Implications ==================== None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittest will be added to tests the App framework implementation. Existing scenario tests will be testing the (default behavior of) kick-start images. Documentation Impact ==================== The usage of the metadata file should be documented. The global (non-datastore-specific) properties should be documented. References ========== None Appendix ======== None

commit_message:
Fix BadRequest message arguments

Although BadRequest does not take 'msg' argument it gets
occationally passed in. A wrong error message gets displayed
as the result (generic default error gets printed).

Code that wants to override the default message should just
pass it into the __init__.

Change-Id: I915dbbd40190fdc6b978e9965b22342f2b347e30
Closes-Bug: 1631473

commit_message:
Add ZypperPackagerMixin to guestagent

SUSE uses zypper as package manager. zypper is also based on RPM so
reuse the RPMPackagerMixin for zypper.

Change-Id: Iafc5589860cdbb2575d080197b86e548a63fc23d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/65/366165/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ZypperPackagerMixin(RPMPackagerMixin): def _install(self, packages, time_out): """Attempts to install packages. Returns OK if the packages are installed or a result code if a recoverable-error occurred. Raises an exception if a non-recoverable error or timeout occurs. """ cmd = "sudo zypper --quiet --non-interactive --no-gpg-checks " \ "--auto-agree-with-licenses install %s" % " ".join(packages) output_expects = [ '\[sudo\] password for .*:', 'No provider of (.*) found.' ] LOG.debug("Running package install command: %s" % cmd) i, match = self.pexpect_run(cmd, output_expects, time_out) if i == 0: raise PkgPermissionError("Invalid permissions.") elif i == 1: raise PkgNotFoundError("Could not find pkg %s" % match.group(1)) return OK elif operating_system.get_os() == operating_system.SUSE: class Package(ZypperPackagerMixin): pass

and the control plane have been related to changes in oslo.context.

Goal here is to reduce the chance of issues when the controller is

commit_message:
Insulate TroveContext from oslo.context changes

Most of the recent issues with compatibility between running guests
and the control plane have been related to changes in oslo.context.
By putting some compatibility code into TroveContext, we should be
able to insulate the environment during upgrades.

Goal here is to reduce the chance of issues when the controller is
upgraded before the guests (which is what every operator wants
to do).

The basic idea here is to introspect the current TroveContext
including the RequestContext base class and remove any unknown
arguments coming off the wire before the constructor is called.

Change-Id: Ia4752c7dfe7bcfedebfaca9f13fb8bc6323d6001
Closes-bug: 1551468
(cherry picked from commit 24c5e8e244380e3e7e309f0b4aaffde32dbf0789)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/95/400495/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _remove_incompatible_context_args(cls, values): context_keys = vars(cls()).keys() for dict_key in values.keys(): if dict_key not in context_keys: LOG.debug("Argument being removed before instantiating " "TroveContext object - %s" % dict_key) values.pop(dict_key, None) return values @classmethod values = cls._remove_incompatible_context_args(values)

commit_message:
[WIP] Security group improvements

This document describes proposed improvements to how Trove makes use of
security groups.

Change-Id: I19facb3f390986024a395c93a12f9bca7050e49a
Implements: security-group-improvements
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/60/389760/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Security Group Improvements =========================== This document describes proposed improvements to how Trove makes use of security groups. Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/security-group-improvements Problem Description =================== Trove uses security groups to limit access to its instances. It does this currently by creating a security group for each instance; this leads to a 1:1 mapping of instance:group. This holds true for clusters where each instance has its own group. This is a misuse of security groups and can be a problem when operators set quotas on their use. It also increases the time required to create instances as each rule is added via a separate API request and the processing time for such requests adds up. Proposed Change =============== Security group rules are determined by the configuration settings of the Trove taskmanager; specifically the tcp_ports, udp_ports, and icmp settings for each datastore. When an instance is created a security group is created with the rules for the datastore and the name is based on the Trove instance id. Therefore a set of instances of the same datastore results in a set of security groups with identical rules but different and difficult to read names. Cluster technologies are often designed assuming some privacy in their interconnection, but the current implementation opens the given ports to all networks attached to the instance. The proposed improvements are to create a security group for each datastore (as the current configuration allows rule customization on a per-datastore level) that lives as long as there is an instance of that datastore. This means no unused group exists and instances requiring the same rules can reuse the same group. A cluster's instances will have a private security group providing access among themselves in addition to the datastore group. The resulting benefits would be a lower number of groups created, improvements to instance create/delete times, and improved security for clusters. A non-trivial part of this proposal is what happens when a datastore security group exists but a new taskmanager config is loaded specifying different ports. The proposed solution is to provide an API for updating a security group which would trigger a migration of instances with the old group to the new group. This migration would happen by creating the new group (if needed), attaching it, and then detaching the old group from all instances using the old group. The old group would then be deleted. Configuration ------------- The proposed change will make use of the existing configuration values governing security group rules. Database -------- The current tables security_group_rules, and security_group_instance_associations will not change. The table security_groups will be modified to look as follows: .. code-block:: python security_groups = Table( 'security_groups', meta, Column('id', String(length=36), primary_key=True, nullable=False), Column('name', String(length=255)), Column('datastore_id', String(length=36), ForeignKey('datastores.id', ondelete="CASCADE", onupdate="CASCADE")), Column('is_latest', Boolean()), Column('cluster_id', String(length=36), ForeignKey('cluster.id', ondelete="CASCADE", onupdate="CASCADE")), Column('description', String(length=255)), Column('user', String(length=255)), Column('tenant_id', String(length=255)), Column('created', DateTime()), Column('updated', DateTime()), Column('deleted', Boolean(), default=0), Column('deleted_at', DateTime()), ) Note the column 'is_latest'. This will be set to True when a group is created and will be set to False when the group is deleted or on taskmanager startup if the rules are stale. Public API ---------- The current {tenant_id}/security-groups and {tenant_id}/security-group-rules will maintain the current functionality. A new resource operation will be added:: POST {tenant_id}/security-group/{id} This will allow update operations on the given security group. This will trigger a security group migration from the current group to the latest group for the datastore. Public API Security ------------------- N/A Python API ---------- N/A CLI (python-troveclient) ------------------------ A new command will be added to run the migration to the latest security group:: trove secgroup-migrate <secgroup-id> The secgroup-list command will display datastore and cluster information and the is_latest status of the group. Instance information will be removed from this view. The secgroup-show command will now display all instances using the security group. Internal API ------------ N/A Guest Agent ----------- N/A Alternatives ------------ Instead of providing a security group migration the groups could be forcibly updated during taskmanager startup. This would involve the rules being modified to align with the latest config. The problem with this is that it forces changes to existing guests which could be dangerous. Dashboard Impact (UX) ===================== TODO Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- TODO Milestones ---------- TODO Work Items ---------- TODO Upgrade Implications ==================== Trove upgrades will be handled in the same way as taskmanager changes. Note that instances using the old style security groups can get the new security group by running secgroup-migrate against its existing security group. Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= The behaviour of when a new security group is created and destroyed will be tested in int tests. Tests involving configuration changes and therefore the ability to test migration may require a new technique. Documentation Impact ==================== The new behaviour and migration technique will be docuemnted. References ========== N/A Appendix ======== N/A

commit_message:
check for user existence, for role add to user

Added code to raise exception.UserNotFound when user not found
in the current project.

Updated the test-case, keystone.tests.unit.test_v2_controller.
TenantTestCase.test_get_project_users_no_user, to assert the exception
when user not found

Change-Id: I227cce3711465e464b23e76b7979ba92861e81ca
Closes-bug: #1614069
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/06/362606/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: user_ids = self.assignment_api.list_user_ids_for_project(tenant_id) if user_id not in user_ids: raise exception.UserNotFound(user_id=user_id)

commit_message:
Add taskmanager_manager in common config options.

Operators/Users need to add taskmanager_manager config in trove
Configuration files explicitly.

If this conf missing in configuration file then trove-taskmanager
will fail to start.

Change-Id: Ia56375f0e95ba55525b2767b8d028636d9f1782c
Closes-Bug: #1633487

commit_message:
Add http_proxy_to_wsgi to api-paste

This sets up the HTTPProxyToWSGI middleware in front of Trove.
The purpose of this middleware is to set up the request URL correctly in
case there is a proxy in front of trove.

The HTTPProxyToWSGI is off by default and needs to be enabled via a
configuration value.

Change-Id: I7b3b974263876ea465cc150581cf77f0c46767dc
Closes-Bug: #1590608
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/95/384395/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: pipeline = cors faultwrapper osprofiler authtoken authorization contextwrapper ratelimit extensions troveapp

commit_message:
Revise the event.rst

To enable the "message" dispatcher, the following line should be added
in senlin.conf:
    event_dispatchers = message
The "dispatchers" should be added with a prefix "event_".

Change-Id: I37eaa4bff7ff36e46c1e025fb26f8ff0ce91dd18
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/39/415139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: event_dispatchers = message

health detection sample.

commit_message:
Fix urllib.urlencode issue in functional tests on Python 3

The urllib, urllib2, and urlparse modules have been combined in the
urllib package in Python 3. The six.moves.urllib package is a
version-independent location for this functionality; its structure
mimics the structure of the Python 3 urllib package.

Partially-Implements: blueprint goal-python35

Change-Id: I423d334bd7d2be5fae19007ddb6408eca381a6bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/54/410554/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update replication property in capabilities

Our current standard capabilities are reporting the nonexistent
"replication" property to the scheduler, and this is then exposed to the
users via the "get_capabilities" REST API.

Currently users will see a "replication" property defined as:

  {u'type': u'boolean',
   u'description': u'Enables replication.',
   u'title': u'Replication'}

And while the definition is correct, the name of the property isn't,
since replication v2.1 uses "replication_enabled" instead, which defeats
the whole purpose of reporting the standard properties.

This patch updates the reported name so it matches existing
implementation.

Closes-Bug: #1642403
Change-Id: Ia39c24d1b256fb3b1d1ee2f1a8c47a04dbb1c3b7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/02/400802/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'replication_enabled': {

commit_message:
Support for node replace in cluster service

This patch adds support for "cluster members replace" in cluster service:
1\ add cluster_replace_nodes in _proxy.py
2\ add replace_nodes in cluster.py
3\ add related unit tests

partial-blueprint: support-cluster-replace-action
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/senlin/+spec/support-cluster-replace-action

Change-Id: I57bb835ae9ca31317b2ddd37958ddbdf64df20df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/19/409419/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def cluster_replace_nodes(self, cluster, nodes): """Replace the nodes in a cluster with specified nodes. :param cluster: Either the name or the ID of the cluster, or an instance of :class:`~openstack.cluster.v1.cluster.Cluster`. :param nodes: List of nodes to be deleted/added to the cluster. :returns: A dict containing the action initiated by this operation. """ if isinstance(cluster, _cluster.Cluster): obj = cluster else: obj = self._find(_cluster.Cluster, cluster, ignore_missing=False) return obj.replace_nodes(self.session, nodes)
